deliberation: The verse is purely spatial and architectural: movement from one court to another and orientation (north, outer court, chambers opposite a structure). I considered whether visionary 'he took me out' could be metaphorical for instruction or revelation, but in the context of Ezekiel's temple vision this describes literal (visionary) movement within a detailed measurement narrative. No metaphors, similes, personification, idioms, or other figurative devices function here.

The verse gives dimensions and orientation: façade, north side, width, depth, all in cubits. The expression אֶל־פְּנֵי ('toward the face/front of') is a conventional spatial term in Biblical Hebrew for the front of an object, effectively lexicalized. I considered treating 'face' as a metaphor for the front side of a building, but here it functions as standard technical language without an active figurative force. No clear or operative figurative language.

This verse continues architectural description: 'opposite the twenty cubits', 'opposite the pavement of the outer court', galleries arranged 'in three stories/tiers.' Terminology like נֶגֶד ('opposite/before') and אַתִּיק ('ledge/gallery') function literally in an engineering description. I checked for any metaphorical use of vertical rising as spiritual ascent, but in context it is straightforward physical structure. No figurative language detected.

The verse describes an access way: 'a passage ten cubits wide,' 'a way of one cubit,' entrances facing north, all toward the inner side. Both מַהֲלַךְ ('passage, walkway') and דֶּרֶךְ ('way, path') are literal here, referring to actual spatial routes, not metaphorical 'ways of life' or conduct. No similes, metaphors, personification, idioms, or hyperbole are employed.

This verse explains that the upper chambers are 'shorter' or 'cut back' because the galleries take away space from them as the construction recedes from the lower and middle stories. Terms like קְצֻרוֹת ('shortened') and יוֹכְלוּ ... בִּנְיָן ('the galleries consumed them in [the] building') could in other contexts be metaphorical, but here clearly and technically describe structural recession and loss of floor area. No figurative sense is activated.

The verse continues the technical explanation: three tiers, no columns like those in the courtyards, therefore the structure retreats upward from ground to middle stories. Verbs like נֶאֱצַל ('withdraw, be offset') are architectural, not psychological or metaphorical here. I considered whether the upward progression 'from the earth' might be symbolic of spiritual ascent, but linguistically it remains a literal engineering description. No clear figurative device present.

This verse notes an outer wall parallel to the chambers, 50 cubits long, along the outer court, in front of the chambers. 'Wall', 'outer', 'parallel', and measurements are all literal. No metaphorical or symbolic usage of 'wall' (e.g., as protection or separation) is exploited at the level of wording here; it remains straightforward description of structure and length.

The text gives the length of the chambers of the outer court (50 cubits) and the total length along the front of the temple (100 cubits). The phrase עַל־פְּנֵי הַהֵיכָל ('along the front/face of the temple') uses פָּנִים again as a conventional architectural term. I considered counting this as a metaphorical 'face' of the temple, but in Biblical Hebrew this is standard spatial language, not an evocative figure. No active figurative language.

This verse describes a passage or entry under/below (מִתַּחַת) the chambers giving access from the east entrance of the outer court. Any potentially abstract sense of 'bringing in' (הַמֵבִיא) is literal: it denotes physical access. There is no indication of metaphorical entrance into fellowship or knowledge here; it's entirely about circulation within the building plan. No figurative devices detected.

The verse states that in the breadth/width of the court wall, on the east, opposite the vacant space and the building, there were chambers. This is another technical spatial orientation statement. Terms like 'breadth of the wall,' 'eastward,' and 'before the vacant space' are literal descriptions without metaphorical extension. No similes, metaphors, metonymies, or other figures are present.

The passage compares the way/passage in front of one set of chambers to another: 'like the appearance of the chambers which are toward the north, as their length, so their width, and all their exits and their regulations and their entrances.' The comparison (כְּמַרְאֵה ... כֵּן) is about literal architectural likeness, not an illustrative simile for some other reality. It is a legal/technical 'just as/so' formula, not a poetic image. No figurative language in the rhetorical sense.

This verse explains the south-facing chambers' entrances: a door at the head of the way, along the corresponding protective wall, approached from the east. Although 'head of the way' (בְּרֹאשׁ דָּרֶךְ) could be metaphorical in other contexts (beginning of a life path), here it's a literal spatial designation (the starting point of a corridor). No metaphor, simile, personification, or idiom functions figuratively in context.

This verse shifts from pure architecture to cultic function: identifying certain chambers as 'holy chambers' where priests who are 'near to YHWH' eat and deposit 'most holy things.' The phrase הַכֹּהֲנִים אֲשֶׁר־קְרוֹבִים לַיהוה ('the priests who are near to YHWH') uses spatial closeness as a metaphor for privileged relational and cultic access to God. The nearness is not simply physical (they serve nearer the inner courts), but a technical, status-laden term in priestly and Ezekiel traditions for those granted special approach to the divine. The other cultic terms (קׇדְשֵׁי הַקֳּדָשִׁים, 'most holy things') are superlative/technical, not primarily figurative. Thus I identify one clear metaphorical expression here.

instances.explanation: The phrase describes certain priests as 'near' to YHWH, using spatial proximity as a metaphor for their special access, intimacy, and privileged service before God, beyond ordinary worshipers or other priests.

deliberation: The verse regulates priestly movement and garments: they must not go from the holy place into the outer court in their service garments; they must leave those garments there because they are 'holy' and put on others when approaching the people. 'Holy' and 'outer court' are standard cultic categories. While they have symbolic significance, the language is not metaphorical but legal and technical: garments are literally set apart for sacred use; movement between zones is literal. No metaphor, simile, personification, or idiom is linguistically operative.

This verse narrates completion of interior measurements, exit through the east-facing gate, and subsequent measuring around the area. 'Finished the measurements', 'brought me out', and 'measured round about' are literal actions in the visionary survey. I considered whether 'measuring' could function metaphorically as judgment, but in this sustained architectural vision it serves literally to define the spatial extents of the temple complex. No clear figurative language.

The verse details the measurement of the east side: using a measuring reed, 500 units. Terms like מָדַד ('measured'), רוּחַ הַקָּדִים ('the east side'), and קְנֵה הַמִּדָּה ('measuring reed') are fully literal in this context. 'East wind' can be metaphorical elsewhere, but here רוּחַ means 'side/direction,' a standard spatial sense within temple measurements. No simile, metaphor, personification, or idiom functioning figuratively.

Again, pure measurement: he measured the north side, 500 reeds with the measuring reed. Same semantic field as v.16, with רוּחַ הַצָּפוֹן ('north side/direction') and numeric data. No symbolic or figurative extension is signaled at the lexical level; it is technical surveying language.

The text continues: measuring the south side, 500 reeds with the measuring reed. As with the other sides, the mention of direction and measurement is strictly literal. I checked for any idiomatic or symbolic use of 'south' in Ezekiel, but here it is one of four cardinal directions in a measurement formula. No figurative expressions.

The verse describes turning to the west side (רוּחַ הַיָּם, 'sea-ward side' = west) and measuring 500 reeds. Though 'toward the sea' is a conventional Hebrew way of saying 'west', it is lexical rather than a live metonymy in this context. The action of measuring remains literal. No similes, metaphors, personification, or hyperbole are used.

The verse summarizes: he measured the four sides, there was a wall completely around, 500 by 500, 'to separate between the holy and the common.' The separation is both physical and cultic, but the wording describes a literal wall whose function is to demarcate areas of differing sanctity. 'Holy' (קֹדֶשׁ) and 'common' (חֹל) are standard priestly categories, not poetic metaphors here. While the architecture is symbolically meaningful, the phrasing itself is not figurative in the narrow rhetorical sense requested.
